Author: andyl
Content:
In my view, America is much safer now than when I was a kid. But that safety comes at a cost - loss of things like freedom, risk-tolerance, independence, trust, self-confidence.

I would have preferred to raise my kids in a free-range culture. For sure, there are many great things about growing up here. But this cultural question would weigh heavily on my decision to bring kids to America.

If you and your spouse are united in your views about child rearing, I'm sure you could pull it off and have a great experience.

Actually I'd bet foreign parents could pull it off much better than native born. Because you'll already face so many cultural changes and can discuss which one's you'd like to adopt or reject.

Also note: culture in different parts of the country can differ wildly. But as a tech worker, you're probably going to land in a region filled with helicopter parents.

Author: harmegido
Content:
Not sure you really answered the question, which I found to be a very interesting one. The OP starts with these two assumptions, which it sounds like you agree with:

1) SMI is likely to occur at some point in the future. 2) SMI is likely to pose a significant threat to humanity.

Given those, it follows that we should be worried and plan for how to deal with SMI at some point in the future, ideally before it is developed. So the question is, what does the world need to look like before we worry/plan for it? And why isn't now a good time to start?

Author: rayiner
Content:
> How the hell did you people let it come that far? I.e. how do people keep voting for these moron politician with their war on XYZ narrative.

My generation (I'm 30) is incredibly paranoid when it comes to parenting, which is really saying something because my frame of reference is my own parents (over-protective asian immigrant boomers). When I was that age, not only would I walk home from school unsupervised, but they had 4-6th graders as "patrols" along the walking routes to keep an eye on the 1-3d graders. My parents thought nothing of letting me walk my brother home when we were about the same age as the kids in the article, and neither did anyone else.

That being said, it should be noted that the place in the article is a D.C. suburb, which means it's full of paranoid, uptight people to begin with. On top of that, like many D.C. suburbs, it has seen a heavy migration of hispanic immigrants in recent years, which has resulted in a lot of tensions. I wouldn't call it representative of the whole U.S.

Author: SpacemanSpiff
Content:
Frankly, as a new parent who lives in the US I am worried that my family would be punished for an action such as what is described in the article. I think that the climate of irrational fear combined with exuberant supervision lead to an environment where decisions which would seem rational to a European could be construed to be dangerous to children in the US. Like walking home unattended. I don't think this fear of coming to live in the United States is unjustified if your values don't entirely match those of the local population.
-- edit --
I also don't think that this kind of enforcement action is a rare event, and that this is why it is being covered in the media. In my opinion, it is being covered in the media because it is a significant example of an event which illustrates the divide in the US between what the majority believes (letting children walk home unsupervised is dangerous) and what a smaller number of parents challenging this establishment believe.

Author: kps
reissbaker
Content:
That's actually harmful for cache performance. Ideally you want many small, granular caches that only expire when the specific content changes to get the highest cache hit rates: if you concatenate everything together, making changes to a single file requires redownloading the entire bundle.

(It's still faster under HTTP/1.1 to concatenate because of the overhead of making multiple HTTP requests and the parallelization limit, but one of the perf gains of HTTP2 is that since extra requests are cheap caches can be targeted and granular. Changes to a single script won't necessitate redownloading a giant concatenated bundle — you only need to download the single script that got updated.)

Author: kazinator
Content:
I used to use a 6502 emulator on a 6502.

Why you would do that is that you could develop and debug code in a way that gives you a lot of visibility into the processor and control: stop anywhere in a non-intrusive way and look at the state of anything.

The only other way to get that would be a hardware debugger requiring a second computer.

Author: Pxtl
Content:
Europe is absolutely concerned with safety... but actual safety. Look at the Netherlands/Sweden "vision zero" initiative - the goal is to get highway/traffic fatalities down to zero.

Compare vs. the USA where over 30,000 Americans die on the road every year. That's like if 9/11 happened 10 times per year, instead of once per century.

My kids don't walk to school alone... and it's not because of my worries about paedophiles lurking around every corner, it's the very real risk that they could be hit by a car - the leading cause of death for their age-bracket.

Author: mmarx
Content:
> higher precision than IEEE, doesn't have rounding errors, and uses fewer bits.

It certainly won't provide higher precision using less bits (precision is lg(b^(l - 1)), where b is the base and l is the number of mantissa bits). For any given base, there are numbers that have no exact representation in that base (for base 10, consider 1/3 = 0.33333…, for base 2, consider 1/10), so it certainly will have rounding errors.

According to [0], the basic idea is to store the number of exponent bits, the number of mantissa bits, and the inexact bit (indicating that underflow has occured) alongside the number itself, automatically promoting/demoting mantissa and exponent as needed, and treating inexact numbers as an interval of width 1 ulp. Thus, the number of used bits depends on the number stored (which might well be less than an IEEE format would use for certain (or even the average) workload, but may very well be more due to the overhead of the tag).

[0] http://sites.ieee.org/scv-cs/files/2013/03/Right-SizingPreci...

Author: ghshephard
Content:
I think the GP is correct - the United States is not the country to move to if you want to have your children grow up independent/free-ranging, at least not right now. For whatever reason, there is a tendency towards helicopter parenting that seems to be the rule, rather than the exception in the United States, and it's reflected in the Laws.

I grew in the late 70s with my 9-12 year old friends like a bunch of savages - our parents would kick us out of the house in the morning, and we wouldn't see them until dinner time - and looking at Google Maps - it looks like I routinely ranged about 1.5 - 2 Miles away from home - and never really thought much about it.

I'd be interesting in hearing more Japanese/Swiss parents feedback on whether their country really is more liberal than the United States when it comes to letting their younger children walk to school in the presence of only another child, not older than 12 years old.

Author: bmelton
Content:
Honestly, it's debatable whether or not you did misread it.

The way it reads, they weren't found innocent of child neglect, they were found to be held responsible for the unsubstantiated child negligence charges.

Their names will be placed in a file, and if the cops responsible pick up the kids again for equally unsubstantiated claims, it will trigger a more thorough investigation. At present, for the next five years, they're on the CPS equivalent of "probation".

Content:

Author: bmelton
Content:
Just for clarification, the "children younger than 8 must be left with a reliable person who is at least 13" is an attachment to a law that attempts to define the regulations for who is and is not allowed to be considered valid as a babysitter.

I know this because my own daughter who has been responsible for years, but only recently turned 13, investigated the matter herself when she was asked to babysit a child while my wife spoke at a conference (and the mother of the child attended said conference) in an adjoining room.

I explained that the situation was a little bit different in that there were plenty of adults one room over, so by the letter of the law, the children weren't being left "at home alone", as the law aims to prevent against, but that she was probably violating the law by not having the required business license and insurance required, which is necessary in Maryland for caring for even a single child.

Author: m_mueller
Content:
How can it be a rare event if it's based on a State law? Am I supposed to trust that the government is not starting to enforce laws I cannot live with?

Also, visiting a country and living there are two very different things. I often visit the US and I tend to enjoy it. But deciding to live somewhere (i.e. taking a job) requires a conscious decision by me to accept the overall societal and legal framework of a place - and I currently cannot do that for the US. In fact I question why there aren't more Americans who cannot accept it. Can something like the Sexual Revolution ever happen again (= a wide ranging transformation of society through a largely non violent movement). Is the grip by mass media and government too tight? Is it just not bad enough to warrant action?

Author: jpatokal
Content:
> More specifically, many Indian recipes contain cayenne,

Cayenne is a city in French Guiana. "Cayenne pepper", on the other hand, is a specific cultivar of the red chilli pepper that's not really used in India (although lots of other varieties are).

> the basis of curry powder that is in dishes like red curry, green curry, or massaman curry.

Those are all Thai curries, not Indian ones!

Author: workingonit
Content:
Uggg are you kidding me?

Why does GitLab have to kill the AGPL instance of Gitorious they aqquired? Most of the people I know who use Gitorious.org did so so we could use an AGPL service to host our repositories. GitLab simply does not do this as it uses a lax permissive license. In addition to this they impose CLAs on any contributors :/ sigh

It is really a shame that GitLab feels the need to remove the only AGPL service that fills this need. I do not know where I will be migrating my repositories, but it will not be GitLab unless they wish to offer the community an AGPL instance.

Author: davemel37
Content:
I suspect this is less about focus and more about conflict with other brokerage houses. Most commercial real estate is owned by an owner-broker who syndicates a deal and primarily makes a good portion of his money off closing the sale, property management and leasing...

In other words, the people they depend on for the listings probably had no interest in sharing leasing fees with them...but are thrilled to be able to list and even pay a premium listing fee.

Focus is the right buzzword for them to spin this...but my bet is that they shot themselves in the foot when they decided to compete with their users.

Author: vijayboyapati
Content: One of the things I found frustrating about Nextdoor when I used it a year ago was that it defines the neighborhood for you. I have a mailing list I created several years ago for my street which has been a very effective way of communicating with each other, especially since we have a street block party every year and a lot of families on the street have kids who play with each other. But there's not way to create a micro-neighborhood where messages only go to other folks in the micro-community (unless they've recently added that feature). When I look at my defined neighborhood now I'm not even sure how they chose the boundaries. It doesn't correspond to neighborhood in the normal sense (capitol hill in Seattle), or to zipcode. It seems like some arbitrarily carved out chunk of my zipcode... weird.

Author: tokenadult
Content:
You wrote,

This right here is the number one reason why I'd never take a job in the US.

Your fear of coming to the United States, which is second only to France as an international tourist destination, and second to none as a net destination for immigration, is irrational. It is perfectly safe to live in the United States and walk about in public. My children do that all the time. (I say so in a comment in this thread that was posted earlier than your comment.) This news story is news because it is a rare event. But what the news story illustrates is that irrational fear can keep people from doing things that are perfectly safe--like letting their children walk about in public, as I do, or visiting other countries, as I have.

Author: m_mueller
Content:
I can't say too much about other European countries since I've never lived there for longer periods of time, but at least judging by what I read I don't quite get your argument. The way I see it there are two aspects of classic liberalism:

* liberal towards persons

* liberal towards organizations

These two often contradict each other, so IMO a place cannot be perfectly and absolutely liberal - it will at best be a balance between the two. The US from what I can judge is extremely liberal towards organizations - kick out tenants, fire employees, influence the government through legal bribery (PACs) - go ahead, no problem (keep your lawyers ready though). Towards persons the US seems to be pretty much the opposite of liberal - the government seems to want to regulate every aspect of people's lives, and if some fall outside the norm there's politicians declaring war on them and introducing more and harsher punishments. In France, Italy, Austria and Germany (=our large neighbours), the tendency is rather the opposite: Relatively liberal towards people, very restrictive towards organizations. Switzerland is a balance between the two, but with the general idea of not restricting anything if it's not really necessary. There's even a third level of liberalism: Towards local governments. Want your own tax regime, with Blackjack and Hookers? Build a new village in Switzerland and let it become an official commune, there you go.

Author: fpgeek
Content:
There's a difference between saying no ("we think larger buttons on our bigger screen are easier to use" or whatever) and mockery ("you'll need to file down your fingers"). Apple could do one without the other.

I understand why Apple uses mockery (better publicity, more memorable, firing up fans, etc.) but, at a minimum, Apple (and their defenders) should expect well-earned mockery in return, especially given their pattern of flips.

Author: peeyek
Content:
With minimum speed of 15mbps to access, it's like impossible for students in developing country which i think they more need service like this for study, research, etc.

For example in Indonesia, in my campus internet speed is only about 3-4mbps.

Scaling infrastructure is hard, i think the future of service similar to paperspace is not a bunch of feature that they offer, but it's more about how they can optimize data compression to deliver full of experience with low internet speed. That's the key to own big market.

Author: nodesocket
0942v8653
Content:
> How the hell did you people let it come that far? I.e. how do people keep voting for these moron politician with their war on XYZ narrative.

I hate to say it, but… we don't really have a choice. You choose either the Republicans or the Democrats, neither of which actually care about the things that matter but instead have, as you mentioned, this odd form of bikeshedding that is intended to make people feel "safe". Not that it actually works, because now we are scared of the government. It's funny how we technically have more freedoms than people in other countries but we have to work so much harder to keep any of them.

Japan and Europe different from the US in lots of ways, but at least Europe in general seems to be less concerned about "safety" especially when it's so impractical.

And helicopter parenting seems to come easily, just as much a part of culture and social norms as it is necessitated by these laws. It's not something that's exactly forced on people but rather something that's accompanied naturally by the decisions of these "moron politicians".

> How come the US doesn't use studies from abroad when doing CP regulation? Boggles my mind.

The US doesn't care about studies from abroad. The US is too US-centric; it thinks it's too different from the rest of the world for those studies to apply.

Author: rtpg
Content:
I'd say JSON is more on the level of s-expression than an ini file. JSON objects are extremely regular (your thing's either an object or a literal), more-so than your standard 2-level ini file. Plus there's a lot of stuff.

Sure, JSON might be a bit more verbose for the "Hello World" scenario, but in mid-range sizes, it's still pretty clear (compared to the verbosity of XML) and doesn't require custom tooling to deal with (like ini files).

There are some formats with less braces (replaced with indents and with less key stuff) that are (I think) isomorphic to JSON that would be nicer to use for everyone involved, though.
